text.p: These are leading stories in this morning's Paris newspapers.
-- President Jacques Chirac is expected to address the country Wednesday, through a text to be published in regional newspapers.
-- Bulgarian president Petar Stoyanov says in an interview he is grateful for President Jacques Chirac's help toward his country's joining European Union and Nato.
-- State considers offering some 30 to 35 percent of the capital of France Telecom according to Industry Minister Franck Borotra, at an estimated price of 170 francs per share.

-- Socialist party spokesman Francois Hollande says in an interview Socialists are opposed to a privatisation of France Telecom, and plan to maintain 100 percent state-owned capital for public services.
-- Finance Minister Jean Arthuis considers reform of French Treasury to improve control and management of state-owned firms.
-- Managers of Eramet nickel mining company answer criticism by their majority shareholder Erap in an open letter published by the newspaper.
-- Financial markets have not yet considered a possible victory of the left in the upcoming parliamentary election.

-- Forty-seven percent of people polled on May 2 and 3 by Sofres for Le Figaro call for a liberal economic policy, while 41 percent would prefer a social-democratic or a socialist policy. Seventy-nine percent see unemployment as the main problem to consider at the time of the vote.
-- Air France Europe, the former Air Inter, plans to maintain almost all its flights today, despite a pilots' strike scheduled for today.
-- Britain signals new era with EMU, new Labour government vows to put into effect Europe-wide social laws.
